This place brings back memories of college and being able to eat on a student's budget.  Now that I have a job I still eat here though.  With a $10 budget this is the place to go.  Beware because it closes at 9:00 on weekdays and 10:00 on weekends.  I have tried many things on the menu but the one thing that I haven't found at other places is the garlic gravy chicken.  Pan fried chicken with the skin on topped with a bunch of hearty gravy with rice and macaroni salad on the side.  Yummy!  This is my comfort food in Las Vegas.  I spent $46 on cabs to get here from the strip for my garlic gravy chicken $10 dinner.  It was worth it to me.

This was the first time I've tried Hawaiian food and let's just say it's left me craving for more! My friends and I came here for breakfast (it was closer to lunch time though, hah) and we decided to share so we can try a little of everything. 

Amongst four girls, we ordered:

Ahi Poke - DELICIOUS! If you are a fan of raw fish, this appetizer is an absolute must. It is chunks of tuna perfectly marinated in some wonderful, addicting sauce with raw onions and scallions. It was so good that we ordered 3 more to-go, just so we can eat it later. This is just one of those dishes that you simply cannot share, because you'll want it all to yourself!!! 

Kimchee Saimin - Comes in a huge bowl with addicting kimchee broth. It is definitely shareable, unless saimin is the only thing you want to eat. I can't tell if this had MSG in it or not, but my friend said it didn't. This dish is very similar to ramen, but the noodle is different. We were only expecting kimchee in our soup, but to our pleasant surprise, there were also pork slices and tofu cubes!

Side of Chicken Teriyaki

2x Spam Musubi - It was my first time trying musubi and I honestly thought it'll just taste like spam and rice wrapped with seaweed. I'm not a fan of spam so I didn't think I'll like it much. But I have to say, it was pretty good... probably thanks to the sauce that was between the spam and rice. 

4x Coconut pudding - For only $1.75, this might be the best coconut pudding I've had in my life. It's hard to describe but the texture and taste of the pudding is very similar to the coconut meat you manage to scrape off the shell after you're done drinking all the juice. It isn't overly sweet nor artificial tasting. I can go on and on trying to describe the taste from memory, or you can go ahead and try it!

We wanted to order more but we were about to go eat again shortly after this meal. (What else do you do besides eat when you're on vacation? ;)) So this "light" breakfast actually turned out to be more filling than we thought! By the last bite of our coconut pudding, we were more than satisfied.

It is cash-only so remember to bring cash! Free parking if you bring your hotel parking lot receipt and food receipt to the casino cashier.

This place rocks!  The food is delicious!  Try the spicy Korean chicken or the Saimin noodles.  Oh, their mac salad  is some of the best I've had.

Great food at a very reasonable price. Go here, eat and leave very satisfied!
Aloha Special - Ocha Zuke! Only $12.95! Very popular eatery at California Hotel. Prompt, friendly service by all. The saimin bowls are huge, too!

First time ever in Downtown Las Vegas and was looking for some dinner. Yelp and our craving for some hawaiian food took us here! I really enjoyed my experience walking through the casino/hotel that led up to this restaurant. It was very casual and no frills. I ordered the Aloha Sampler which had a little bit of everything. Service took a bit longer than expected but the portions are generous. If I'm ever back in Vegas, I'd make a stop back here.

Oh em gee!  Where to begin!  For a former local who now lives in Vegas, this is the place to eat when one is missing the island flavors!  Much better than the L&Ls here in town.  The food at Aloha Specialties is so much more flavorful.  When it gets busy, though, be prepared to wait...both to order your food and for your order to come out.  They should open up another register so that the line to order food doesn't get so long and people don't get restless waiting to order...especially our kupuna.

A hidden gem inside the California Hotel. I've been coming here for years, even before I became a Vegas local. And being a local, I prefer DTLV to the strip. Don't expect white linens or pretentious food. This place is all about that good stick-to-your-ribs kinda food. Definitely comfort food to the max (probably good for hangovers) Good prices and large portions, what more could you ask for? The plates they use to serve the food are the biggest plates I've ever seen, haha! I wasn't able to finish my meal so I boxed up the left overs. I went during a weekday afternoon. No line whatsoever, so that was a plus. We ordered the SAIMIN, KOREAN CHICKEN and BEEF STEW. I wasn't a fan of the SAIMIN. A bit too fishy for my taste. The KOREAN CHICKEN was very tasty, a bit on the sweet side. The BEEF STEW was awesome! I highly recommend that. I got a side of green onions too which really made the dish. In hindsight I should've asked for a fried egg on top. Perhaps next visit. Side note if you have time or room for dessert, Lappert's is right next door. You'll find all the flavors you'd expect from an IceCream shop based in Hawaii. So Ono!
The staff was excellent, but  food was meh- not bad, just bland, nothing special about it. Portions were good, though, so this would be good for big appetites.

Hawaiian food for the soul.

Environment:
Located on the second floor of the Cal. It's an open restaurant that has seating "outside" (aka in the hotel walkway) but small. Expect a wait on crowded weekends, especially tournament weekend! Order and pay, and they will deliver the food to you. They bus your tables for you.

Food:
I've always loved their saimin, but this year I was sad that my saimin wasn't HOT. It was warm. The noodles were great like usual, but the broth tasted like tap water. Bummer. After I added my shoyu and hot mustard, I was in saimin heaven. We ordered a side of kim chee (pass on this) which was not good and probably out of a grocery store jar and a side of mac salad which was good BUT had too much mayo and was too salty for my liking. The mac salad had good texture, crunch, and color though. The portions are huge! My bro ordered the small saimin and it was comparable to a regular portion at any ramen house in socal. I ordered the chicken and tofu saimin and I think it's served in a large bowl. The chicken was moist (thigh meat?) and the tofu was regular cooked tofu. The haupia was firm but the flavor was bland.

Why four stars?
Nothing compares to my grandma's cooking, but if I'm in Vegas, this is as good as it gets for Hawaiian food, especially saimin.

This place is the main reason why my friends and I initially frequented California hotel & casino.  They have some great Hawaiian food at an affordable price.  This place tends to get packed but it's worth waiting.  Luckily, this time around, we made our way here a little after the lunch crowd had already left.

Got their Aloha plate ($10.99) which includes chicken teriyaki, beef teriyaki, 2 spam musubis and macaroni salad.  I forgot that this doesn't include rice because it comes with 2 spam musubis so I went back to order some rice ($1.25).  This proved to be pointless because I only took 4 bites of rice and also had 1 spam musubi left over.  The beef teriyaki can be a hit or miss sometimes.  Unfortunately, the beef was somewhat tough this time around.  The chicken teriyaki was great though.  I also like their mac salad because it doesn't seem too heavy.

Once you order your food, they give you a number to put on your table.  They bring over your order and you're on your own after that.  There is a table near the entrance with cups and water dispensers with ice, as well as to-go boxes.  Oh and make sure you've got cash because this place is CASH ONLY.  This is the only reason why this place isn't 5 stars for me.

Food is decent but if you're by the door when waiting in line, it will legitimately take 45 minutes just to get to the cash register. This is the slowest moving operation ever I don't even know how they can move this slow.

Kool Hawaiin restaurant in the hotel California.   Place doesn"t appear anything fancy, but food was really good & everyone who worked there was super friendly.  Went for the Loco Moco dish and it was excellent.

My first two visit back since the reopening, and I still got the cheeseburger. Still my favorite. And I like the macaroni salad even more because it is not as lathered in mayo or salty as it used to be. However, the kim chee and spam musubi wasn't like I remembered. The kim chee was a bit too vinegary, and the rice on the musubi was to bland. Fortunately, the hamburger/cheeseburger is my go-to dish there, and that's still great. The portions are still huge and the last time, I had a taste of the teriyaki chicken, and that tasted great. Before, I thought I would try the other dishes, like the saimen, but the portions on many of the items are too big more me, now, and I think that consideration is out for me, unless I can share a dish with someone else.

Very good for a Hawaii-style restaurant in Vegas! The chicken bowl was HUGE and the chicken had this yummy grilled flavor. The beef stew was delicious, had soft meat and was so on point!! I felt transported back to Honolulu!

Food: (-1star)
Definitely a Hawaiian local favorite. If you walk into a restaurant and most of the customers you see are Hawaiian, that tells you something right? 
-Local plate: the chicken was good. The beef didn't have enough of that charbroiled flavor/texture (not enough heat) and they pan-fried instead. Their teriyaki sauce was quite good though. Light yet still holds that flavor and spice in it. Musubi has too much rice but was still quite good. I finished it. Go figure.
-Loco Moco: Hamburger meat a bit dry but flavorful. Egg wasn't over soft/medium cooked (runny) like it should but over hard. Over-fried is more like it. So this is main part i didn't like about this dish. Their gravy was actually good and worked perfectly. 
Overall, i actually liked this place more than a few places i had in Maui. Just cost alone made me happier here.

Price: 
Very descent. Loco moco plate ($7.50) and Local plate ($10) which has teriyaki beef & chicken and 2pc of spam musubi. Their portions are very generous too!

Ambiance:
Very casual. As you walk in, seems like a regular dine in pad but you actually go order first and pay, then go grab your own table. They have a water table where you can serve yourself and they will bring you your utensils. Place is clean but very casual like where it may seem unclean and a hole in a wall to some. Generally a laid back place. 

I do want to say this place may be more 3.5 than a 4 and not that bad to be a 3. Knowing for the good bang for your buck, portion and i know ill be coming back despite a few flaws, i kept it at 4 stars.

This place is the real deal.  Food here is more authentic Hawaiian than food in Hawaii.  I LOVE this place and we go every time we visit the Premium Outlets.  The spam musubi, saimen, and the local plate are my favorites.  The sweet and sour spare ribs are good too.  On the local plate you get beef, spam musbi, and teriyaki chicken and rice and mac salad. Wish I could substitute the sweet and sour spare ribs for the beef.  The beef is just meh.  The teri chicken is PHENOMENAL.  The skin is crispy and the sauce so perfect.   Not too sweet or salty - just perfection!!!  OMG, I'm craving a local plate now that I'm writing this review.  I could eat at this place 2x a week - not that it's good for you.  The restroom outside of this restaurant seems very well kept and clean compared to other casinos.  Only downside is that this place can get crowded.  Sometimes you have to share a table with someone.  The other downside is that it's in a dive of a casino in downtown that is filled with cigarette smoke.

IDEA FOR MANAGEMENT - Wish they would open a location in HENDERSON - on Eastern perhaps.  Please?  I beg you!  And how about one in TORRANCE, CA?  Pretty Please???  It's urgent.  My craving for local plate is out of control.
Big portions of local favorites! Had the Loco Moco and it was delicious, but not enough gravy. The garlic chicken is nice chicken thighs, pan fried with brown gravy. Yum!

Whenever I'm in Vegas with my family and friends, Aloha Specialties at The California Hotel and Casino is our go-to spot. This is the Hawaiian restaurant upstairs, right across the famous and delicious Lapperts ice cream shop. I've never seen this place empty, this place is always packed and the line is out the door. I really love their new look, they've remodeled and updated their restaurant with newer seats and tables, paintings are nicer and the service is faster. I also love that their fruit punch still tastes like Malolo brand Hawaiian style.

I normally go for their Portuguese Sausage and Eggs (sunny side up) with a side of Mac Salad... It's the closest thing to feeling like your in Hawaii, ordering from Zippy's or the Rainbow Drive-In. Another favorite is their Saimin which comes with noodles, fish cakes and wonton. They also have really good combo platters, they have a choice of Kalbi short ribs, chicken/pork Katsu, bbq pork, beef/chicken teriyaki, which comes with white rice and macaroni salad. Make sure to save enough room in your tummy for some yummy dessert at Lapperts ice cream and try their tasty flavors like their macadamia nut ice cream!

My family ALWAYS comes to this restaurant... There's a reason why it's crowded!! The line was out the door and the wait about an hour long. I got the 2 eggs with rice and Portuguese sausage (so good, my mom was surprised with the amount of food I ate... And they aren't stingy with their food!!). The spam was extremely salty (this is from a girl who LOVES her salt) but my mom seemed to like it :) the rest of my family got Siamin noodles (sp?) keep in mind that the large is HUGE. I have no idea how my brother ate that... The macaroni salad is a must in Hawaiian cuisine and the kimchi tasted like kimchi (which was to be expected). My only issue is with the seating. It would be so much more organized if they had someone seating people! However I can't really complain as we were able to find a seat pretty easily (which was EXTREMELY surprising given the amount of people there!)

FREAKING YUM!!! There is usually a huge line, and for a good reason. The food is fantastic, and the prices unbelievable. The portions are ginormous. I have never left here hungry. It is one of those places that you have to unbutton your pants if you eat your whole plate without taking any home to-go. 

I usually order chicken chop steak. Every time it is super fresh! The bean sprouts nice and crisp along with the fresh celery. It tastes like good home cooking. A great portion of meat as well, they definitely don't skimp.  The rice is always spot-on and mac salad to die for! It's like there is some secret ingredient that makes me always want more even after I am stuffed! The bf got bento plate last visit. We have never ordered anything that we turned out NOT to like! Of course as a staple to our meal was the kimchi. MMMMMMMMMMMMM!!!!! A small bowl that seemed to never end. It is delish above the rice as well. Pickled goodness! 

I almost feel like this place severely under-charges for the amount and quality of the food. I would gladly pay more. The staff is friendly as well and always helpful if you have any questions or prefer sriracha sauce instead of what is already on the table. The restaurant is always clean, even though they are so busy.

Food was good and pricing reasonable. Clean tables and floors. Bathroom was clean and karaoke room is separate from dining area. Great place for family, friends and karaoke. Service was good and prepared fast. The decor has a industrial rustic with Hawaiian Music to set the mood.

After a long vacation and drive from San Fran to LA to Vegas ending up at Aloha Specialties made me feel like I arrived back home on Oahu.

Seeing all the local people, local food, ......home away from home!  The food is ono, the portions are huge, and they have Hawaiian Sun Passion Orange!

Definitely a go to place for Hawaiians!

Awesome. So my friend found this place his last time in Vegas. I was a bit skeptical about the place....I mean it's in the California Hotel on the old strip...not exactly what you think about when you think good eats.But I do remember folks on here talking about a Hawaiian place, so I was hoping this was it. 

BINGO!!!!! This place is money!!

My friends ordered the Korean BBQ Chicken and I decided to be different and get the Garlic Chicken with Gravy. So each order comes plate style....meaning it came with rice, macaroni salad and HUGE amounts of chicken. 

So there is no waiter service and everything is boxed up like you are getting it to-go. This was cool as they were able to serve lots of people in a short amount of time.

The Korean BBQ was spicy and had great flavor. The Garlic Chicken w/Gravy wasn't as flavorful but was still good. I really liked the kimchi here but unfortunately it was an add on item. I thought the macaroni salad was a bit salty.

This is the best place in town to get authentic Hawaiian food!! I have never been disappointed with the food and the service is great too. The ladies that work there want to be sure you're happy and comfortable. The kahlua pork & cabbage is by far my favorite dish. If I lived closer to the California Hotel, I'd probably eat here a lot more. I love it!

OMG, tasty Hawaiian  local food with portions fit for a family! Tasty chicken teriyaki, sis had the large won ton saimin (fed our entire party of 7), bro had the Local plate lunch of two types of Teri, rice, mac salad, pickles, other sis has the Kalua pig/ came mixed in cabbage (ok), other sis has the spam musubi, she liked!  We rolled outta there and hit the black jack tables to burn off them calories.....oh, and there's a Lappart's Hawaiian ice cream shop next door for awesome ice cream ----dang it, off to the gym to burn off those 1000 lushious calories!

Before moving to Vegas, my friends and I would always pay a visit at the 'California Hotel' (Downtown Vegas), not to gamble but to eat at this hawaiian bbq spot. I've never been to a bad hawaiian bbq restaurant but I could tell the difference from O.K. versus a  Better tasting place..

Beef Teriyaki, Loco Moco, Ribs, Spam Musubi, Portuguese Sausage are all very good choices. But I must say that their Teriyaki Chicken was fluffier than most I've tried and their Teriyaki sauce was so rich, thick (gravy like) and tasty!

Much Better than O.K. tasting Hawaiian Food!

If you want some tasty reasonably priced hawaiian food this is the place to go. Its inside of the California hotel and casino on the second floor. This past time I ordered the aloha breakfast which came with eggs, rice, spam, Portuguese sausage and what they call luncheon meat. Very filling meal and if youre in the mood for breakfast it hits the spot. The spam was  not too soft had a slight crisp to it (just the way I like it) and the Portuguese sausage had goof flavor. The luncheon meat was interesting. I would compare it to a thick piece of bologna. 

You seat yourself here and order at the cashier. There's only one cashier so when it gets busy you may have to wait. They only accept cash here so dont be coming in with a credit card. But then again you're at a casino so getting money shouldn't be an issue.
This place is so good! Born and raised in Hawaii, best place to go in Vegas for local food.
A little hidden gem if you're looking for Hawaii food. This is a good comfort food spot that I always like to stop by when I'm in Vegas. Food is delicious and menu has a wide selection.

Went here a couple times while I was in town for a music festival. 

Portions are kind of huge but huge because it's chocked full of fillers like rice and carbs. 

Coming from a major metro city with tons of Hawaiian, Asian, and fusion flavors of all types and qualities, tiny flavor rating for this spot isn't all that great, but not bad either. Get the job done

If you are eating to get full as fast as possible, which I sometimes am, come here. 

If you are looking for flavortown or ambience, which I often am, go elsewhere.

This is one of the best hawaiian food place in vegas. Granted its a hole in the wall (of a casino). 
I ordered the "local plate" 2 spam masubi, teri chix/beef and a side of mac. I enjoyed my plater very much. While my other friends ordered the "bento box" and the teriyaki bowls. For the price they had for the bowls, I shouldved ordered one! it was much more than my "local plate". Well I was craving spam masubi, so I my stomach was telling me to buy it vs the other specialties. A buck fifty for a tall drink, sold! vs one of the specialty canned drinks (also for the same price).
Some of my friends dogged me for eating spam masubi (they dont like spam or seaweed). So I tell them "life is short, enjoy and eat it up" besides, they're missing out on some good food!
decent prices, I'm coming baack for some more grub! :)

I worked downstairs  at "The Market Street Cafe" during the graveyard shift. I was not aware of this place in the begining. As time went on, former islanders would talk about this place and that the food was great. So as a skeptic, I went on my day off. I was in for a surprise! Not only is the food great...but their portions are generous! I really recommend the Korean Beef and Korean chicken combo! I watch the servers pass with the bowls of saimin, yet my friends tell me that "it's the REGULAR" then I see a much larger bowl..."THATS the LARGE!" All in all, I recommend "Aloha Specialties"

As I already stated I have been coming to Aloha specialties for over 10 years. In the last year, coincidentally around the time the owner died, I think it was the owner.. whatever the case, in the last year this place has taken a turn for the worse. The food is progressively getting horrible, the wait times are long, I will go back but i don't think It will be anytime soon, sad day.
Can't get enough of the good "local" food here. Open early and just late enough to get saimin or whatever plate lunch you crave. Always has great service and terrific prices too.

My friends and I come here as a traditional goodbye lunch before heading on home from Vegas.  It's a drive from the strip considering it is inside the California Hotel.  It's apparently a popular place to go for lunch so it's best to go there early if you're really hungry.

The food comes out relatively quick and it's tasty.  I ordered the teriyaki plate for $7.25 and they give you a good amount of food.  Ask if you can get double chicken or double pork and exclude the pork chop.  The pork is hard and is a pain to eat.  The teri sauce is good and not overly sweet.

Located inside the California Hotel in downtown Las Vegas. What a gem. This place has the best Hawaii type food outside of Hawaii. Had the Aloha bento ($8.95), large saimen add wonton ($7.00) and ahi poke ($4.95). All very tasty and portions are huge! The Aloha bento is on their special menu and consist of teri beef, korean chicken, mahi mahi and hot dog on rice with furikaki and some little side stuff like fish cakes and takuan --the highlight was definitely the korean chicken. The ahi poke had huge chunks of fish, super fresh, as good as poke from Hawaii --had a little too much onions and not enough limu but the freshness and quality of the fish more than made up for it. I originally hesitated with the ahi poke just because I thought it might be grey and stinky but it was far from that and definitely exceeded my expectations. Last but not least, the saimen really hit the spot on a cold winter day. Probably would skip the wonton next time, I thought the wrapper was too thick and doughy.

This place is nothing fancy...very casual, friendly staff, tables have cheesy hawaiian print plastic covers. The wait for the cashier to take orders is slow sometimes as she is also pushing food out from the kitchen and making people's drinks. Come here for good food, nothing more, nothing less. Cash only.

Been coming to ALoha Specialties for over a decade. Glad to see that they have remodeled and expanded their restaurant. There is now much more seating and space....

The food here is delicious. The portions are large and decently priced. Definitely get more than what you pay for in comparison to other hawaiian spots. I always leave Aloha Specialties stuffed and satisfied. My favorites are the Garlic Chicken with Gravy and their Loco Moco. Meat is proportioned well with the rice that the meals are served with. Recently tried their Portuguese Sausage with rice and egg, which was appetizing as well. The sausage was a little on the salty side when eaten without rice, but balanced perfectly when scooped and eaten together...

I would give Aloha Specialties five stars, but the line to order is horrible. It has grown in popularity and is always busy, so it takes forever to order your food. They only have one cash register, which is part of the problem. When renovating, they should have added a few more registers (or even at least one more at the minimum) to prevent such delays in ordering. I will say this though...It's evident that all the employees work hard...every worker is always busy and on the go with their duties. While occupied though, they are still always happy to help.

Note: cash only accepted

Food was delicous! Great prices. Definately a place to Come back to. One the 2nd floor. Cafeteria type seating, comfy and looks to be a place that is always busy because of their ridicously good food!! $20 got me a large plate of food and a side I was too full to eat. Definately a must try!

Hungover from the night before and wanting to explore the Old Fremont Experience for the nth time, I had the strongest craving for a Loco Moco.  And thankfully, I found this gem.  It's located in the California Hotel & Casino 2nd Floor. It looks like an old-school Hawaiian diner. They have noodles, teriyaki chicken and of course, Loco Moco.  

It completely satisfied my craving, I even asked for an extra cup of gravy to douse my rice in.  I'm surprised I didn't gain any weight from this most recent Vegas trip.  But I have Aloha Specialties Restaurant to thank for my cured hangover.

The second highest population of Hawaiians are located at The California Hotel in Vegas. It's true! If you've been at this hotel, you'll know what I'm talking about. You know this place is good since you'll notice the amount of old timers here. 

Aloha Specialties is my must visit when I'm in town. It's the same order every time. Garlic chicken served crispy on both sides. Gravy on the side. Comes with three slabs of chicken, rice, and mac salad. Hawaiian Sweet Punch is a definite must. One of these days, I'm going to ask them to spike it with vodka. I always forget to ask. 

Nothing fancy. Just good comfort food and friendly people.
I'm usually not a fan of teriyaki sauce but this one was really good. Cheap price with large portions. I recommend it if you're on a budget

First time I came to this place was a few years ago and the prices were CHEAP!! I think the ox tail soup special was $6-7 at the time. About 10 years ago. 

The last few times I've been here the portion is extremely small. Before they gave 7-8 decent size chunks but the last few times I got 3. Wtf is going on?? Also it's $9.99 now. The steak is even worse. For $6.99 it came with super oily and soggy fries. Let your fryer heat up before cooking fries!! The veggies are oily as well. The steak have a bunch of gristle and tendon. 

Also the service is always bad here. They would literally take your order and drop it off. They never come check up on you or even refill your drinks. I'm sticking to south point from now on for my grave yard specials. Steak is only $4.99 there and the burger special is $3.75

I love the Aloha Bento! Giant portions and it has everything Mahi Mahi, Redondos Hot Dog, Teri Beef, Korean Chicken and Furikake Rice. Better than most Hawaiian places in LA and very nostalgic for me, I've been staying at the Cal since I was a kid. I always eat here when I'm in Vegas.

Soon as you get near the restaurant, you'll see a gathering of people visiting from Hawaii. If you too are from the 808, you'll recognize a variety of menu items that are common in the islands. If you're not from the 808, some of the items may seem unfamiliar. It's comfort food from Hawaii.

The prices are reasonable. Mostly under $10, comparable to the prices in Hawaii, sometimes even less.

Ono grinds. Good Hi food. saimin, beef stew, musubi, teri beef, chicken, all the usual. If you've never been to Hawaii, this is a good introduction/representation.

Serio, it's not a slice of pineapple on a burger to make it Hawaiian, that's not how it works.

Food is consistent in taste, quality, and presentation.

Hawaiian food is always good here.  A lot of the locals come here.

They have a great menu and there is always something for someone.  Food was good like usual!

It is cash only so don't forget to bring your cash.

My vegas vacations would not be complete with out stopping here for my lau lau plate,saimin and teri sticks...This is the place where people from the hawaiian islands come to eat to get their taste of home....everything here is onolishes(very good).Authentic local food,plates big enough to take some back to your room for later.Don't be surprised if there is a long line.It's worth the wait...Come here and enjoy.(p.s. the sports book is on the same floor around the corner.So can run and go place your parlay card while you are eating)..heehee..Enjoy aloha specialties in one of my favorite towns.....Vegas baby!!!!!!!!!!!
I come here every time I'm in vegas. The Korean Spicy Chicken and Saimen are some of my favorites. Delish good home cooking. Big portions, really nice people, and very reasonable prices.

I'm taking away 1 star from this place since they didn't have won tons for my saimin.  How can you run out of won tons on a weekend?  This place is still my favorite place to eat when in Vegas.  Nothing like great, authentic island food without leaving the mainland.
They forgot my fucking food... And they weren't even busy, how the hell you forget to make someone's order when it's empty....

Customer service here is pretty bad... Guess they ran out of the boiled peanuts and while waiting one of the girls come by and said "we are returning your money we ran out of boiled peanuts" she didn't even offer to ask "can we get you something else"?? She was just really RUDE!  I am not going back here!  Food was just okay.

This place offers amazing and affordable food! They are located on the second floor of the the California hotel/casino...

The food is really fresh and authentic! They have anything from soups to rice bowls... we ordered the Wonton Saimin, which has eggs, char sui pork and veggies with ramen noodles. Their spam masubi's a great appetizers and their garlic chicken is a must! If you are in downtown Las Vegas and are looking for a quick, cheap and delicious meal, I would definitely check this place out! You walk up and order at the counter and the seats are first come first serve.

Newly remodeled but the line is worst than when it wasn't remodeled.  Cashier moves in a speed of turtle .  They don't care there's a line...customer service isn't was it used to be.  We got here at 2:15 after lunch crowd- so we think but it'a nearly a 20 min wait to place your order & another 20 mins to get your food.  Cost of food has gone up.  I don't mind it if it wasn't a pain to stand in line & see how slow the cashier work.

My family and I have been eating at Aloha Specialties over 30 years, and it's because they have the best Aloha dishes outside of Hawaii. Like the new upgraded ambience and still affordable consistent prices.

My friend recommended this place however I am not a fan of this restaurant. This is an Asian  fusion restaurant but predominantly Hawaiian food. I got the Teriyaki plate which included steak, pork loin and chicken over rice with a side of macaroni salad. The proteins were thin, almost paper thin! The rice was hard and undercooked. It was drenched in Teriyaki sauce and it still was not edible. The only thing I liked was the macaroni salad. 

I do not recommend this place and will not be coming back.

Its like reuniting with that old flame that you can never quite forget.  Before it expanded, it was the typical HOLE in the Muther Effin Wall.  Did a fly by biz trip in the area, so i went to reminisce.

Small Saimen
Curry Chicken Platter
Large Fruit Punch

So damn cold in vegas last week....but oh so perfect a meal.

Have yet to experience a bad meal.
Y

If you're from Hawaii and visiting Vegas, you will definitely LOVE this place!! Once I tried this place for the first time, I had to beg my boyfriend to keep coming back to eat. Definitely makes you feel at home. Their garlic chicken and fried saimin were delicious! The staff were also very friendly. Who knew you could eat such good local Hawaii food in another state?!
The newly remodeled with more seating and modern design same great menu. Order the teriyaki beef bowl with mushrooms and onions. Very good.

I'd just left the place 15 minutes ago.  I ordered my food to take home at around 12noon today.  The lady at the counter definitely does not represent the meaning of Aloha. She seemed to have permanent frown, doesn't smile  and so rude.  They gave me my number but did not explain whether they will call out my number and I have to pick it up at the counter or they will bring it to my table, which was only 2 feet away from my table where my number 100 was fully visible.  So I patiently waited. 20  minutes later there is still no food and I didn't hear anyone calling out my number. After 35 minutes my patience has run out.  The old man who cleans out the tables saw my number and he saw my to go order has been sitting on the counter and he told me to come over.  He said they normally call out the number and I told him I didn't hear anyone calling out my number.  He handed me my order and I was about to leave when I realized I'm missing another order of spam musubis. So I came back for my order, the rude woman did not even apologize and instead looked at me as if annoyed.  The food was great but the service was horrible - I will never ever come back again.  This is NOT the only place that serves Hawaiian food.

Everything is just ok here, nothing to rave about.

I tried the chicken teri, korean chicken, mac salad...it was all just ehh

CASH ONLY

One of the reasons I love downtown Las Vegas is that they cater to people from Hawaii.  Because of this, there is always an eating establishment serving up local food.

I shared the poke, aloha saimin, and korean chicken plate with my girlfriend.  

poke: I don't know that I would get this again.  It's not what I really expected.  The tuna chunks were too big, and they were swimming in sauce.  The taste was still good though, but we didn't finish it.

aloha saimin: I usually don't care for saimin, but it was pretty good.  Lots of wonton, fish cake, and charsiu pork.  Most importantly it was very tasty.

korean chicken plate: this was a special, so it might not always be on the menu.  It didn't taste very korean at all, nor was it spicy (which it advertised).  However, it still tasted great.

Best of all, the prices are very reasonable.  They had a lot of other good looking food, and I wanted to try it all.  The next time I go downtown, I will definitely hit this place up.

You can't go wrong with a true Hawaiian restaurant inside of the only hotel in Las Vegas that caters to the Hawaiian customer.  If anyone knows anything about Sam Boyd and his love for Hawaiian then you will appreciate and understand why this hotel would have some of the best local Hawaiian food in Las Vegas.

I have never been disappointed eating here, maybe the only thing that bothers me is they don't accept credit cards, CASH only.  It is located on the second floor of the California hotel and casino in downtown Las Vegas just a block from Fremont Street.  If you are in downtown and want some good Hawaiian food then please give this place a try and you won't be disappointed.

Some of my favorites include Spam Musubi, Kalua Pork, Saimin, Beef Teriyaki bowl, and the Mahi Mahi Sandwhich; along with daily specials you can'it go wrong.

Aloha.

Love, love, love the Hamburger Steak here!!  It is a must have every time i stop in Vegas.. A homemade freeform hamburger patty topped with slightly grilled onions and brown gravy.  Mmm... I hate when you order a hamburger steak and it's a processed, machine pressed, hamburger patty that was made for a burger..  Totally not cool.. Wheres the love? Wheres the Aloha? You get the complete opposite here, this piece of meat was made to be a hamburger steak!  whatever spices and flavors they put in there are great!  You can taste the love and the Aloha!  Mmmm aloha... then top it with gravy and a grilled onion?!  I think i could just eat the gravy and rice!  but thats me, I'm known to do that even at thanksgiving!  The mac salad is good too, soft and creamy and goes even better with some of the gravy on top too.  What goes better with fat then MORE fat??

The other thing to get here is the Korean Chicken.  Spicy, but sweet and salty all at the same time..  The best way to describe it is a spicy teriyaki chicken cooked on the grill top.. 

And for the plane or car ride home don't forget to pick up a few spam musubi's.  No respectable person from Hawaii would leave home with out it.

Pros: one of the best hamburger steaks, even better than most places in Hawaii.. korean chicken, mac salad are good too.

Cons:  they don't take the Vacations Hawaii coupons and some of the items are just okay.  Cash only.

Advice: avoid peak lunch hours.. it can be really crowded.  Located between the bridge between the California Hotel and Mainstreet.

Bomb! Went walking to this place with my friends from LA. I insisted on making them try it since I saw the high yelp reviews. We finally find it after walking around downtown lost, hungover, and hungry. 
It was all worth it thou. Very casual setting in a beat up old casino. Out ordered garlic chicken covered in gravy. BEST!!! Hawaiian gravy I have ever had. The staff was very nice, and the food came out fast. 
Its always a good sign when you walk in and the place is full of Hawaiian customers.
I just wish they had chicken katsu. :( Overall,  a diamond in the rough of downtown las vegas

Our friends took my husband and I here for breakfast before we hit the outlets.  The food was so good and inexpensive.  They give you big portions can't go wrong with this place.  My friends did good taking us here. Tho my husband was looking for hash browns...  I felt like I was in Hawaii in Vegas.

If you're craving a taste of the islands, you cannot go wrong with this place.  It's a casual order at the counter kind of place, so don't expect anything fancy.  It's just big portions of gut busting Hawaiian standards.  I ordered one of the bento combinations and my wife ordered the kalua pig and cabbage plate.  Each were excellent and very budget friendly.

This place has great food and the prices are cheap with large portions! If you love Hawaiian food then this is the place to go. I've brought plenty of visitors here and they all love it just as much as me. I usually get a teriyaki bowl, saimin, spam musubi when I come here

The only downsides are that it's CASH ONLY and there aren't too many tables which makes it tough to sit when it gets packed and it does get pretty crowded in there, especially during the lunch hours

This place is great.

If your planning on having lunch or dinner expect a very long wait. It goes very fast though considering that its a small restaurant. Seating is hard to get so have one person order for you and the other out looking for a place to sit. 

This is the place to go for cheap good portioned food. 

Haven't tried everything but every time I come I order the teriyaki bowl (that comes with white rice). This is huge and the beef is sooo tender and the teriyaki sauce is sweet but not over powering. I love it! It tastes soooo good. maybe someday I'll take a chance and order something else.

Least favorite thing about this place is that they accept cash only! How inconvenient! Oh well, its def worth it.

I would go more often but its 30 minutes from my house.

Located on the second floor of the California Hotel, Aloha Specialties is a small resto located across Lappert's Ice cream. I've tasted several dishes here including the garlic chicken, regular saimin, kim chee saimin, chicken and tofu saimin, grilled saba, spam musubi, grilled teriyaki salmon, and chicken katsu. First thing that comes to mind when I eat here is Hawaii comfort food at its best. They all taste very good with an especially generous amount of rice.  I wish they could give other sides instead of just mac salad though. Other than that, Aloha Specialities is a pretty good place if you miss your ono kine grindz.

I would say this is as good as it gets when it comes to Hawaiian food.  I've been to Hawaii many times and this is pretty spot on.  The serving size is great.  Me and my husband shared a Local Plate, that came with two spam masubi's, teriyaki chicken and beef and mac salad.  We also shared a wonton saimin soup.  It was a huge bowl and we didn't even finish it.  I'm not too crazy about the wontons but the saimin broth and noodle was very yummy.  This place is very busy.  You line up and order your food then you grab your seat.  The turn over is very fast lots of people eating here and the wait is worth it.  The price of our bill was only $20 and we were stuffed.   Dont' forget to save your receipt to get your parking validated.
Cute little place. Very busy when we went. In the California Casino. Decent prices. Fairly big portions. The macaroni salad was so-so. The Chicken dish was nicely flavored. Overall, okay.

I enjoy places that provide a great value for the money spent on food. This goes back to how much I did not enjoy paying for going out to eat in California, because it is always so expensive. I originally heard about this Hawaiian restaurant from a Teriyaki Hawaiian Restaurant owner / chef friend from California. He had stayed at the California hotel, which is where this place is located, and decided to act on his recommendation. Good thing I did! I have been eating here for over a year and they only have raised prices once to an acceptable level. I always get the flash combo bowl chicken no skin & beef on a mound of sticky white rice. I then order a small saimin, which is huge, if I'm still hungry or if I want to share it. Two things that could make this restaurant a home run, accept credit & debit cards & have a healthy brown rice upgrade option. They promptly close, so be on time!

I would eat here every day if I could.  Prices have gone up since i started going but it has been a few years.  This place is awesome, and I am not hawaiian.  I can only speak about the chicken rice bowl cause thats all I ever get.

Been coming here since I was a kid and when it was located where the restrooms are now! Lol. 
Never ever had a bad meal here! Ever!
Always fast, always fresh, always on point Hawaiian food! I go here at least 2 times a month! I'd go every week if it wasn't where it's at but its all good.
Love this place!!!!!!!!

Located in the California hotel downtown I'd have never stopped here if it weren't for yelp!  You order your meal at the counter then seat yourself!!  My party's food came out very quickly and not all at once.  The saiman came out first and I enjoyed it a lot!  My Boca plate was ok but the spam was very salty although that should be expectedand the rice had seaweed on it, it wasn't that bad but not my style!  The chicken is breaded and fried, that and the beef were just ok!  I might come back but only for saiman!

They close pretty early for Vegas. A must stop every time i'm in Vegas, great comfort food. My personal favorite by a long shot is the Kalua pork, it's like a shot of hawaiian flavor in your mouth with each bite. saimin and fried saimin are very good, if you're craving soup the saimin is where it's at. spam masubi could use a thicker cut of spam, my brother and i make better, at least in my opinion. the korean chicken was pretty good, good flavor and not too salty. i'll be here again in OCT for the LA KINGS frozen fury, so you know where i'll be stopping by to eat.

If you are a tourist comin to Vegas, take some time to visit the historical Vegas downtown and come to the Aloha specialties.
It is one of the authentic, Hawaiian family restaurant and it is affordable and delicious.
Glad i brought my family for the Aloha breakfast...well worth the trip and money!

We will be back!

Hawaiian food is a nice change in Vegas. Food is average. The portion size is kinda small and they try to make it up with the rice. I ordered a loco moco with over medium eggs, patty was so dry and the egg were cooked completely through.

I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!  Located on the 2nd floor of the California Hotel and Casino in downtown Vegas, lies this little restaurant.  My fiance and I come to Vegas several times a year, and stopping here at least once during each trip is a MUST!  We come here mainly for the Saimin with the wontons .  So amazing!!!!  They have the best Saimin ever!  Don't even try comparing Aloha Specialties Saimin with L&L as there is no comparison.  We also like ordering the teriyaki plate which has teriyaki chicken, beef and pork with a side of white rice and macaroni salad.  Their macaroni salad is to die for.  Mix their macaroni salad with a little bit of their thick, oh so yummy teriyaki sauce and it's like you have died and gone to heaven.   In addition, they believe in giving you generous portions and have reasonable prices. They have a good sized menu too, with a little something for everyone. Service is always friendly.  The only downside is they take cash only and at times their lines can be long!   And when I say "long" lines, I mean lines that go way out, past the entrance to the restaurant.   To ensure you aren't waiting in line I give this piece of advice.  Go before noon or after 2 pm to avoid the crowds.  Yes, folks, this place is that popular!  When you do decide to make a trip, make sure to wear your stretchy pants.  LOL!  :D
Good hearty Asian style breakfast, brunch, lunch. Chicken, good.. crispy and moist. Platters are huge. Saimin was excellent. Long lines, but worth the wait. Mahi Mahi was pretty fresh.
Saimin was flavorless. Korean chicken was pretty good. So were the musubis.  Good service. But try hawaiian hale. It's better.

If you're in downtown vegas and visitIng Hawaii, chances are you're gonna eat here at least once. For those of you that aren't, this place is pretty much equivalent to local food found in Hawaii. I got the aloha plate and everything about it was ono.
Amazing food and everything on the menu is great! But this place can be pretty crowded but it is well worth it!

What restaurant is empty at noon but packed like crazy at  3 pm?  A Hawaiian restaurant of course!  

This is the epitome of good ole fashion Hawaiian food outside of Hawaii.

We ordered:

Fried Saimin--4 Stars
Regular Saimin-- 4 Stars
Classic Breakfast with eggs, portugese sausage, & rice- 4 Stars
SPAM Musubi
Haupia

Costs: $
Cheap, real effin cheap, especially for Vegas.  On one of our trips, we ordered a drink, the breakfast, saimin, spam musubi, and Haupia and paid $14.00 total.  

Service:  GAZILLION STARS.  Yes, it's slow when it's busy but aside from that, they are very friendly just as you would expect from a Hawaiian establishment.  They are beyond homey.

Altogether, what I like about this place is that it doesn't wreak of refinement if that makes any sense.  The way that it's served, you would think you're at home.  Well, I should say the BF's home since they're Japanese Hawaiian =)

P.S.  THIS IS NOT A FILIPINO RESTAURANT as it says on the info, it's not even close.
Fu**ing the Bomb!! Taste just like it does Oahu! It reminds you of being there and the people are just as friendly.

only tried a couple of items here short rib & an all meat platter with chicken ,pork chop and beef . all was pretty good and cheap and you get a good amount .also you may get tired of buffets. they sell cookies and t shirts at the counter. if you get a chance go to vegas 808 it is across the way it has all kinds of snacks !

If you are on a low-carb diet you can order the saiman without noodles and with veggies instead. I think I was charged around ~$4. They gave me bean sprouts and napa. Also still had the roast pork with it. Still a decent serving size and was pretty filling.
Flipping delicious best hangover food ever.  I used to work at L&L and I love this place more.

Surprisingly good!  
It was like street food in Hawaii
I truly love and enjoy this place. Everyone is so friendly and the food is ono. I always get the ochazuke with side Portuguese sausage. It's so onolicious. Great way to end your Vegas trip.

Aloooha!

Alright back to writing reviews from our roadtrip.  I think all the reviews hit the mark with this restaurant...esp if you're a local from the HI....it's no Zippy's but when in Vegas, will take it.

Staying in the California Hotel aka the 9th island, it was great having a place like this to go to especially if you've been on the mainland for quite some time. Got myself a spam musubi and the aloha bento special...definitely not a place to go to if you're on a diet...was laden with fat, sodium and grease like any good ole spam can and made with aloha.

Just remember, this place is technically separate and independent functioning from the hotel so CASH ONLY...no DEBIT, no CREDIT, and you can't charge to your room..it was also super hard finding an ATM around the hotel and the only one I could find is the one downstairs between the main lobby and the entrance to the casinos.

Brought our friends here for lunch and the decor of this place has been upgraded, new menu, bright decor and just more attractive and comfortable plus they take credit cards besides cash now.  We ordered the kalua pork plate, the local plate and the garlic chicken.  The portions were humongous!  Food is tasty but the macaroni salad was alittle on the bland side.
Koren Chicken is amazing! If super hungry...Order the fruit punch with an extra piece on chicken and mac salad.

This review is long overdue as I've been here more times than I can count, over the years. 

The California Hotel & Casino is like the capital of the 9th Hawaiian island, known as Las Vegas. If you're from Hawaii, you know this to be the truth! Take a stroll thru the casino - the odds of hitting the lottery are better than never seeing someone from Hawaii. 

Anyway - some locals like to go the California to eat at Aloha Specialties. Somewhat reasonable prices for decent portions. This last visit, I had a bowl of Saimin with won ton and a side of macaroni salad. The Saimin broth is ok but the noodles are a little thick and a little chewy. Won tons - too much dough. I prefer to have more meat filling. A little on the chewy side too. To clarify - not a crunchy chew but bordering under cooked pasta. Al dente.

Macaroni salad - made with too much mayo. I love mayo but if you take a look at my pics, it was like instead of using one entire container of Costco size mayo, two were used. 

Walking in - get in line to place your order then find seating. No table service. Your order is brought out and if you want water or refills, there's a water station. I can't speak as to refills as I opted for water. 

I know I have posted other reviews that are critical of "Hawaiian" restaurants. This one is no exception. Having been born and raised in Hawaii - I'm not a fan of this place and I only went because family was craving one of the dishes served there.

Service here could be better but since I really enjoy their food I can't complain much. I've tried pretty much everything, every time I visit my Aunty here in Vegas from Cali. I think it's so funny that people travel from Hawaii only to come and eat here on their vacay. The lines can get pretty long. And customers sometime sit down on a table without a number. I really like their saimin, bento plates and spare ribs. Sometimes the ahi poki can get a pit chewy. I can never go wrong with their spam musubi.

If there's one thing I miss about living in Hawai'i, it's the food! 

Somehow, my mom convinced us to dine here this past Sunday during one of the busiest weekends of the year in Downtown Las Vegas. We made our way to The Cal, which by the way is THE hotel to stay in if you're from Hawai'i, in case you didn't know. Vegas isn't nicknamed the 9th Island for no apparent reason, people! We reached the top of the escalator and my god, I've never seen a line so long for a plate lunch!

This was my first time dining at Aloha Specialties, so I wasn't too sure if the line was always this long or if it was just because we were waiting with a third of the festival goers from Life Is Beautiful. We patiently waited for about 45 minutes or so before placing our order, but I didn't mind because it gave my indecisive ass some time to figure out what I was in the mood for. 

I was back and forth between the Hamburger Steak with grilled onions or the Spicy-Korean Chicken. My sister ended up ordering the Spicy-Korean Chicken and I figured I could just sample hers and order my Hamburger Steak! Winning!

The portions at Aloha Specialties are more than generous. Let's just say that I couldn't even see my plate because it was completely covered with rice and brown gravy. I love my rice, I'm Filipino for crying out loud! But I personally think that my plate came with way too much rice. Not to mention the size of the Hamburger Steak was about the size of the plate. Talk about overwhelming! The Hamburger Steak was thin and crispy, just how I like it, but it could've used a little salt. There's no way I would be able to finish my meal alone. Can you say kanak attack?

Spicy-Korean Chicken- Not your typical Korean fried chicken! Aloha Specialities nailed it with this one. The chicken is extremely flavorful and moist, but the best part is the crispiness of the skin! 

My mom swears by their saimin! I tried some of the broth and it was just okay to me. Not the best, but it wasn't bad either. There was a big variety of vegetables in it too.

As a (now) Vegas local, I appreciate the fact that there are many options to choose from when I'm missing the flavors of the islands and Aloha Specialties is now on my go-to list for when I'm craving a taste of home. I would highly recommend this joint to everyone. Great food and friendly service. 

Shoot, even the Hawai'i locals can't stay away from the food when on vacation here in Las Vegas! Needless to say, the line is worth it.

This establishment is located inside the California casino on the 2nd floor.

After 2 months of renovating I am finally able to come back after the renovations
Cons:
~45 minute wait in line (this maybe due to their outdated POA system and/or person(s) operating the cash register)
Health Grade of C (Yes you read that right)

Pros:
Food is delish (if your willing to buy food at a place that has a C rating)
Consistently good food
More seats inside
Modern (ambiance, seats, tables, etc.)
Spicy Korean Chicken (my personal fav)
Loco Moco got better (idk maybe I havent had loco moco in a while)
Prices
Right across an ice cream eatery

FYI Saimin is now only one size (used to be small or large saimin, not a big deal tho!!)

To be honest, there isn't many cons for this place, but the two I stated can be serious gripes. The food is consistently on par in quality and taste. The place is clean. This place isnt a 50 shades of grey on my tastebuds, but its delicious.

Finally they upgraded their C grade (health code) to an A

If your in need of Hawaiian food to neutralize you appetite try this place out, its been good enough for me to eat at this place for the past couple of years.

Came here on a Sunday afternoon after visiting the Natural History Museum. My husband and I used to come here back in the 2000's to eat and we wanted to show our kids this place since they have never been. 
We ordered a Teri Combo, Sweet & Sour Spare Ribs, and Teri Burger. The food was good, but there was a bit of a wait because they were busy. 
We would come back if we're ever in the downtown area craving Hawaiian food.

This place is DISGUSTING. I have no idea how it gets a 4 star. We picked this place because of the reviews and how close it was to Freemont where we were seeing a show. My party ordered the Teri Beef Sandwhich, Aloha Buntie and the Sweet & Sour ribs. All the meat was fatty and not of good quality. Yes, I agree it is cheap and you do seem to get enough food, but it was awful. The reviews mentioned the Teriyaki which to me was very sweet and tasted like it came out of can. Seriously people this is what you have resorted to as good food. GROSS. I will never eat here again or recommend to anyone. There are SO many other good places to eat in Vegas do not waste your time. Also, what restaurant doesn't take credit cards. Its the 21st century get with the program, its called running a business. Idiots!!!!
For all you foodies in the mood for Hawaiian food. Dis place is da hook up. The food won't let you down. The look is new, but the food is onolicious.

Wow I crave this place.
Serving sizes are awesome.  Love the loco moco, and the combo plate here.  Very hearty.  Great portions (probably too big).
Spam musubi is bomb here.

But the biggest hit is the kimchee saimin.  The bowl is huge and there are so many tasty ingredients.  And their noodles are really really good.

We drive downtown just to eat lunch at this place.  Unfortunately they aren't open real late at night.  Forget what time, but around 9pm or something.

This place has quickly become a staple on all of our Vegas trips.  Since we frequent this area now cause the vibe is so much nicer than the dooshie strip clientele, this has become a must-go for any meal.  I have noticed that I've catered my selection based on the meal too.  

Breakfast: Loco Moco.  Classic favorite and well executed here.  
Lunch: Kim Chee Saimin.  Soup soothes the soul.  
Dinner: Combo plate or Korean Chicken. 

Yes, I can come here for all 3 meals... and yes, I actually have before.  

BTW, if they're closed, then you're probably on vegas time and haven't seen the sun in a while.  This just means you need to go downstairs and get the ox tail soup.  You're welcome.

I ordered the Chicken and Tofu Saimin. I've never had saimin before so I didn't know what to expect. It looked like ramen but the noodle texture was a lot more tough as if it was not fully cooked all the way. The broth was good but salty. I ended up just drinking the soup and eating the chicken and tofu. This place is really out of the way since it's not on the strip. I probably will not be back. :(

pretty delicious hawaiian favorties. probably the best Hawaiian in Vegas

Korean chicken and wonton saimin are bomb! and mahi mahi. Nice big portions. Always one of my favorite spots Downtown.  food always tastes fresh unlike most hawaiian chain restaurants. i love that the California Hotel caters to its Hawaiian cuzins =]

Don't understand why people enjoy this restaurant so much. What's all the hype about?

Anyways, I've come here several times and several times have told myself to never come back here, yet I always seem to give this place another shot. However, after many chances, I will not come back here ever again. 

This place is crowded all the time, again, I don't know why. We waited around 30 minutes just to order our food around 11:30 am. Ordered the saimen with wontons, fried saimen, and curry chicken. We all shared so we can try a little bit of each. Saimen and wontons both had no flavor whatsoever, fried saimen tasted nothing like how it should taste (bland, sugary, watery), and curry chicken was HORRID. It was like the left over chicken with skin still left on it. The curry was not strong enough either, so it tasted watery. Just overall BAD experience here. Cheap food, but horrible.
The Saimin was really good. Get there early to avoid the long line.

YUM! Came here yesterday for lunch and had a great meal here with a few Californians and Hawaiians.  This place can get pretty crowded at lunchtime, so make sure to get here early before everyone wakes up or checks out of their hotel rooms. 

I had the local plate, which was 8.95$ before tax.  Definitely a good deal as the portions are big, filling, and tasty.  The local plate comes with two spam musubi, chicken and beef teriyaki, and a side of macaroni salad.  I wasn't too hungry, so I was able to eat all but one spam musubi, which I foiled-up and packed-up for my airplane ride back home.  

Take out boxes and foil is located near the front entrance, just below the water dispenser in case you want to take your leftovers.  They also accept credit card now (sorry, no AMEX).

Overall, a great filling meal that won't hurt your wallet. It's great to find some good quality food options that aren't too pricey like most of Vegas.  Aloha!

Oh damn. Talk about legit ono local kine grindz! My aunty insisted we go here when we met up in Vegas and boy, am I happy she did!

The selection here is winnaz and the food itself is good enough to compete with my favorite plate lunch places back home. Expect a line when you arrive though! Especially if the cashier is talking story with co-worker or a customer.

The smaller wonton min portion is HUGE and the mac salad is delicious. You will definitely eat well and leave with a nice food baby. 

Definitely coming here again next time I'm in vegas.
Aloha Specialties was a favorite hang-out spot for me in high school. I've many fond memories of the cheap chicken bowls and fruit punch we consumed there.

I had high expectations after reading some reviews, but this place didn't live up to the hype. I had the chicken dinner. It was a lot of food, but the quality was horrible. My chicken was 50% skin and fat. If you are looking for a moderately healthy or don't-want-to-give-yourself-an-immediate-heart-attack-dinner go elsewhere. I think the deep fried oreo down the street is better for you.

This is a must on my list whenever I'm in Vegas. Where else can you grab an amazing (and huge) bento plate, play some slots, listen to folks talk in Pidgin, and sit next to a WWII veteran from the 100th Infantry Battalion? 

The Korean chicken plate, bento plate, and saimin are my favorites here.

No trip to Vegas is complete without  a meal here!

My little girls love getting a bowl of saimin, spam musubi, and 'sprunch' (sprite and fruit punch!) My fave is the Spicy Korean Chicken- not very spicy and doesn't taste very 'Korean', but REALLY good! You can't go wrong with a protugeuse sausage/eggs/rice breakfast here ever!!!

Yes it's in the Cal (gasp!) DOWNTOWN... but we like to eat here before or after our stop @ the outlets on the way! It's a nice, relaxing break from the craziness of the strip, and it's fun sitting at the machines with all the Hawaiian 'aunties' and 'uncles' :)

I was a first timer here but loved what they offered. The food was amazing and the service was great. I ordered the Korean chicken and was able to take a lot to go still. The portions were huge and the prices were reasonable. I just wished the set up of the restaurant was better and a little more updated. Other than that, it's a good place to go for some Hawaiian food.

We had a hard time finding this restaurant, which is on the second floor of the California Hotel. We had to stand in line to order at the counter, but the food was delivered to the table and came out pretty quickly. We both had the teriyaki combination plate, which comes with chicken, steak, and pork, white rice, and a small macaroni side salad. The teriyaki sauce was tasty, but the meat portions were small and a little gristly and the chicken thigh was cooked with the skin and fat (which I typically don't eat). The macaroni salad was pretty good.

Be aware of "C" rating The order taker hands out cups lip side down on counter where people put their money  very unsanitary. Limited menu a lot of island favorites gone. Personnel not friendly. Tables not cleaned off immediately for such a small place. I saw a server pick up a dropped fork and place it back in the usage bin. Plus is new fountain station not limited to one drink. New decor.

Not going to pretend I'm from Hawaii or anything and say that this place is authentic. However, after visiting Hawaii and eating plenty of the local food, I can say that it comes somewhat close. 

I love me some hamburger steak so that's what I ordered. There wasn't enough gravy but the taste, rice and mac salad made up for that. I enjoyed it very much. 

My family and I shared the large saimin noodle. The soup wasn't very tasty (I think I'm just used to ramen broth) but everything in it was good. It just wasn't like "OMG THIS IS DELICIOUS."  We also had some korean chicken, which was pretty good. I would have preferred it to be crispy all over just not on one side though :p 

Overall, it was a great meal and the portions are a good size. I think it's a tad pricy, but it IS in a casino (California Hotel and Casino). The line is long, so expect to wait. Also, seating is limited. I would come back if I had some extra time during my next Vegas trip and was seeking some comfort food.

Kalua pork and cabbage was indeed great.  The chicken and veggie bowls are nice value though too heavy and sweet for me.  An abundance of rice for all entrees. Counter service friendly and restaurant full of Pacific Islanders for guests.  Spam and related items on the menu but I didn't try them. On the SECOND floor of the California Casino.  Very smokey casino which is unfortunate so I probably will not be back.

You wouldn't expect this Hawaiian restaurant on the 2nd floor of a casino to have amazing food..... But it's amazing! The cheeseburger was so savory and juicy! I wanted to get more. I was originally upset I couldn't get fries with my burger but the macaroni salad is a perfect palette pleaser to accompany the burger. My friends orders the Flash Bowl, with chicken and beef (teriyaki on rice) and is was also sweet and delicious! The place is spacious and a nice calm getaway from the Vegas Fremont, just a block away. They only thing is that they only take cash!

If you like Hawaiian grub, this is the place to eat at - 

Its in the upper level of the California Hotel & Casino. We used to hit this place up all the time when we came to Vegas. We were in town last weekend and decided to come here for some breakfast. I ordered my usual Loco Moco - a bed a rice, 2 hamburger pattys, 2 eggs over easy and gravy all over. 

Good stuff - if you're in downtown go check this place out

Light snack some drinks
"Ox Tail Soup"
POGIBALLS overall rating 4 Stars
Food 4 Stars
Service 4 Stars
Restaurant Cleanliness 4 Stars
Restroom 3 Stars

     This soup was the perfect dish for after a  night of drinks.  The meat on this oxtail was falling off the bone and very tender and juicy. A little too much fat but still the broth mixed with the meat and the vegetables made the dish very good. This soup accompanied with some steamed white rice made it a perfect after midnight snack.
     
I would dine in here again. @Aloha Specialties / California Casino,  Las Vegas

First time at the restaurant, and it was great. The portion size for the noodles in their bowls compared to the prices was amazing. The Selection of foods had a nice variety. The customer service was good & very kind. I will be sure to recommend & come back to try the other foods.

This is the spot to go! I had the salmon teriyaki and it was delicious!!!! Big portions and friendly staff!! You could also call in your order and pick up, which is what I usually do. Teriyaki chicken bowl with veggies under $5 is awesome!!

This restaurant is located inside the California hotel in downtown Las Vegas.  The whole hotel has a very Hawaiian feel to it.  This restaurant is very casual dining.  You order at the register and the food is delivered to your table.  The portions are huge!  


I had the Loco Moco and it was delicious!

Yes to Portuguese sausage, eggs, and rice, with a side of Aloha Shoyu.  Yes to real plates and silverware instead of plasticware and styrofoam trays you'd get at a drive-in like L&L.  And yes to all the Hawaiian decor that makes you really feel like you're back on Oahu.

No to their breakfast prices.  We paid $5.75 for a breakfast plate, which is the same amount for the breakfast buffet downstairs, which also serves portuguese sausage, eggs, and rice.  However, if you don't want to wait in line for that buffet AND you're not that big of an eater, Aloha Specialties upstairs of the California is a fine option.
The best spot for local food in Vegas. Huge portions and great prices.  Also filled with locals so you feel right at home on the 9th Island of Vegas.

Let me set the mood

Its 2 p.m the day after New Years eve.

Me and my boyfriend were HUNGOVER damn near still drunk from the night before (Don't judge We're in Vegas people! ) lol
Whats better to eat when hungover than some soup....

Walked in and the line wasn't too long maybe 10 people in front of us...

We're both super dizzy, and its so stuffy and hot in there! No air flow at all...

It took us LITERALLY 45 MINUTES just to get to the register to order. Service is VERY slow

They had only two girls working. Both running out food, and only one of them were taking orders so basically she would take a customers order, and then do about 10 minutes of delivering food and waiting on customers already seated.


Anywaaaaaayyyysssss

We ordered 2 Large 'Saimins' & 2 sodas. The total was $27.   (One Soup is more than enough for 2 people to share)

We sit down, our food comes out maybe 15 min later, we ate a few bites, then I see my boyfriend looking at his bowl with a weird face (Weirder than it already is) haha

Me : "what"

Him : "Is that a "F***** Bug"

Yes, Yes its a dammmmmn bug in our soup that we waited almost an hour to order, and eat.

He scooped it out, placed it on a napkin and flagged down the server. 

She came, and quickly snatched the napkin out of his hands, crumpled it up, and said I'll refund your food. (as if this happens frequently and she was following a protocol)

Geeezussss...

They refunded his soup, (NOT MINE) even though I told her I no longer wanted mine as well since I was completely grossed out from seeing a bug in his.
Our soup looked like it hadn't been touched they were practically brand new I could have sold it to someone standing in line.


Wouldn't come back

I think I'm being nice here and giving 2 stars because I don't want to completely ruin the rating since the flavor of the food is good. But I prefer my meals with less "Natural" proteins. Thank you.

If you are looking for Hawaiian food.. this is da place.
We had the saimin, Korean Chicken and Combo plate.  Feels like Hawaii or Gardena  lol!
If you enjoy hawaiian food or need to fuel up before hitting the table, this place is great for big portions of tasty grub. The only drawback is they can take awhile to complete your order.

Great place to go if you're missing local island food! Today we both had the Korean Chicken Plate. As usual, I couldn't finish it all and took most of it home for another meal. Will have it for dinner tomorrow night, since we are having a special Easter dinner tonight.
Came here to try spam musabi for the first time. It was amazing. The spam was nice and crisp. Can't wait to return

For a smallish Vegas themed restaurant they have some great food. Their prices were also really reasonable even by Denver standards let alone Vegas prices. The staff was really friendly and really quick to get the food out. 
We ordered the fried saba which turned out to be a whole half of of a fish with macaroni salad (a Hawaiian tradition) and a few large scoops of rice. It was a really nice change from the 3 inch square of fish that you'll find in most restaurants. We also split the ahi ahi poke, which was under $5 for a bowl filled with ice cube sized fish chunks. The sauce that it was swimming in was a little sweet but the cut of fish was pretty tasty. Some of the other bowls that they were carrying around were the size of a medium pho bowl and other plates were piled high with meats and rice so you can safely assume that you'll get your money's worth. 

I would like to go back again..... 
Today!!

Who would have thought you could find this island gem in the middle of the Vegas desert? Aloha Specialties delivers on so many levels.  We opted for the Aloha Breakfast, Aloha Bento, small saimin and teriyaki salmon...and 4 Spam MUSUBI to go.  To feed a family of 4 was less than $45.

For a person who can eat cups upon cups of rice, Aloha Specialties satisfied my starch hunger and fulfilled my daily intake in one sitting.

The Aloha Bento was a plateful of rice, fish, hot dogs, chicken and beef teriyaki. The Aloha Breakfast contained a variety of meats including Spam and the ever popular luncheon meat. Only those with a taste for meat in a can will distinguish the subtle flavors between Spam and luncheon meat.  The small saimin was actually a medium in some ramen restaurants.  The salmon was probably the smallest of the dishes, but came with white rice and macaroni salad.

The ambiance is great with 98% of the diners from Asia.

In all I give them an A+++.

Mahalo

I love this place!   I must return next week.  

Hawaiian food plate, its just so tasty.  The macoroni salad was insane, the terriaki beef out of this world with this sweet gravy on it, and the rice was a perfect match for soaking up the beefy gravy.   I ate my whole plate, was not stuffed, just satisfied.   Happy, ready to swim at Hanalei Bay in Kauai, but back to the 9th Island Vegas!  Thank you Aloha and see you again soon....brahdahs and sisters....

5 STAR HAWAIIAN DELI PLATES HERE!! 
Cheap and yummy! 

Inside the California Hotel

AS is a nice option for some simple Japanese Hawaiian grub. The only thing that keeps plaguing me is that the rice is always inconsistently mushy. My friend's spam musubi didn't have mushy rice but 1 of my 2 was. And my combo plate had. Wed that was overlooked and cut in small bits. The Portuguese sausage never disappoints but really can't mess that up too much when cooking it. 

The service is always spot on. So I always have mixed feelings. There just isn't an option like it in Vegas and sometimes you want homecooked food. 

Renovated interior but food could still use an upgrade.

Simple, cheap, and tasty.

If you are going to visit this restaurant, you will probably want to beat the lunch crowd rush as the line goes outside the door.  I usually go around 11:30 or so where you can just walk up to the register and order.  The food is very typical of a hawaiian plate lunch, but it makes its teriyaki chicken like a katsu instead of just simply BBQing it.  All in all, it is very good, very cheap, and very Hawaiian.

The portions are Hawaiian fat boy Big Kanuha style and absolutely delicious. Upon arrival the restaurant was very very clean and the staff extremely courteous. I felt like I could take off my shoes and stay a while. With the look of a couple staff members, my pants too. Boing!!! I always order the loco moco extra sloppy (like my kisses) and it did not disappoint. I recommend this highly if you like Hawaiian/Asian food. These meals always make me super horny, so I try to eat here 15 times a week. Boing!!! Aloha and see you next time.
My saimen fix always good ;) every time when family comes to the mainland we usually hit up the cal :)
Wow, this place has really good local style food. It would do well in Hilo due to the amount of food and cheap prices.  Kim chee saimin and a flash(chix/beef) bowl with 2 drinks only $15 total!

FOR THE LOVE OF GOD BRING CASH TO THIS PLACE. To get cash in this casino takes longer than booking an airline flight. The food is decent - I had the local combo plate which included spam musubi - but they could use more staff to keep up with the orders. That being said the place is popular (all the tables were full) and it's different than the standard tourist fare on Fremont Street.

Every time I'm in downtown, I come to this place for some loco moco. U can order it during any time of the day. Super good, but not super good for u. If ur in the mood for some authentic Hawaiian good while in Vegas, this is the place to stop. Has a very mom and pop type of feel. It's located just up the escalator on the second floor of the California club.

Always a tradition to go here when in Vegas with the fam.

Likes:
-Cheap food. 
-Pretty good Hawaiian food. I've had their saiman, Portuguese sausage with eggs and rice, and spam musubis.
-Big portions.
-Service is fast.
-Casual, take-out place.

Dislikes: 
-Cash only.
-They bring you the food, but everything else is self-serve, such as getting cups f water and utensils.

Recommend:
Yes! Good place to stop by before leaving Vegas...pick up some spam musubis for the road!

My son was torn between the garlic chicken and the Korean chicken; the guy at the cash register said Korean chicken, hands down. We ordered that and a locals plate  with two Spam musubi, teriyaki chicken and teriyaki beef, and a scoop of macaroni salad. It was all delicious. Even though we were really hungry, we took plenty of leftovers back to the hotel for a midnight snack. We also got a pack of macadamia chocolate chip cookies that had no preservatives, only the ingredients you would use in cookies made at home -- so good. 

Remember, cash only and no coupons, but definitely worth a stop!

It's a Universal truth that the first first thing to do after checking into your downtown Hotel is to head straight to Aloha Specialties.  Nothing kicks off Vegas like a Loco Moco. It sets the tone for the whole trip. You never want to get into Vegas and start drinking on an empty stomach. This is the perfect place to eat to put some rice and some delicious meats in you.
It's an okay place. It doesn't have an elaborate menu and it's hidden within the casino.

Got a "chicken and beef bowl" but it was huge! Lots of rice, chicken was good and beef was like steak chunks, kinda tough. Would just get chicken next time. 

Also side if mac: just cold mayo and mac. My sis says that's true Hawaiian style but I'll skip it.

Bf got the chicken bowl and spam musubi. It was good but only get one. 

The food is homey, like you can make at home. I can see why the Hawaiians and people like my dad love this place.
Got food poisoning on the first few bites. We didn't even finish our food. That's a complete no, and doesn't compare to other Hawaiian BBQs in the area...
We always eat here where in Vegas the food is good and the price is excellent .we always order the aloha vento the best plate.

Haven't been here in years ever since we''ve been staying on the main part of the strip for all that glitz, glam, tourists and crowds. But occasionally we like the quiet local joints in this part of the city. Nice change of pace! 

No nonsense Hawaiian joint. Good food, great service with great prices. Stop by after you check out the Fremont Experience can't go wrong. But bring cash as they do not take cards.
